RADIO STATIONS • WKAR • WKAR-FM July 3, 1968
Mr. Ken Clark
Project Director
Programs for the Disadvantaged
NAEB
1346 Connecticut Avenue N.W.
Washington, D. C. 20036
Dear Ken:
In response to your memo of June 27,* let me fi„rsfc congratulate you on \
your recent appointment and suggest that whatever assistance I may
provide in your worthy campaign is yours for the asking.
WKAR has one series of programs on the road and one in the formative
stages which excites us. Two months ago, we learned that the conven¬
tional news outlets in Lansing-East Lansing and surrounding areas had
not been covering the efforts of the poor to campaign locally and nation¬
ally to raise money for'legislative petitions or to facilitate communica¬
tion between the poor of the community and the remainder of the community.
In fact, further examination of the problem revealed that neither newsr
papers nor the broadcast stations in the mid-Michigan area covered any
news or efforts of the disadvantaged.
Contact with spokesmen for the disadvantaged resulted in a program series
(one-half hour weekly, minimum) broadcast once on each of our stations
(AM & FM) which provides continuing examination and dissemination of in¬
formation about the problems of the disadvantaged in our coverage area
and the implications of the solutions. Initial efforts by WKAR have been
well-received by the disadvantaged and advantaged alike. One spokesman
for the poor stated, "For the first time we have the opportunity to say
something with the knowledge that we'll be heard!"
